content.title: JUST ENERGY TRANSITION PARTNERSHIPS JET-P
content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 3

content.text: This lesson explores Just Energy Transition Partnerships (JET-Ps) as innovative financing mechanisms to support developing nations in shifting from fossil fuels to clean energy. It emphasizes blending public and private capital to phase out coal, upgrade grids, and retrain workers. Challenges include ensuring equity, avoiding debt traps, and integrating grassroots priorities into national strategies. Effective governance and inclusive frameworks are stressed to balance economic shifts with social justice and accountability.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: blended finance mechanisms
concepts.body: Blended finance mechanisms are financial strategies that combine public and private funds to support projects, particularly in developing countries, aiming to leverage additional investment for sustainable development.

concepts.title: grassroots-to-national alignment
concepts.body: Grassroots-to-national alignment refers to the process of ensuring that local community initiatives and movements are connected and coordinated with broader national policies and strategies, promoting coherence and mutual support between local actions and national goals.

concepts.title: just energy transition partnerships (jet-ps)
concepts.body: Just Energy Transition Partnerships (JET-Ps) are collaborative initiatives aimed at ensuring that the shift from fossil fuels to renewable energy sources is equitable and inclusive, addressing the social, economic, and environmental impacts on communities and workers affected by this transition.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 3 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: JET-P as a financing mechanism

content.text: JETPs are innovative mechanisms that assist developing countries in shifting from fossil fuels to clean energy sources. They provide financial support for phasing out coal plants, improving electrical grids, and retraining workers, especially in countries in the Global South that need substantial backing for a sustainable transition. The first JETP was launched at COP26 in Glasgow, where South Africa secured USD 8.5 billion in funding from countries like France, Germany, the United Kingdom, the United States, and the European Union. This initiative quickly gained momentum, with countries such as India, Indonesia, Vietnam, and Senegal joining.

The JETPs' focused and collaborative approach—supported by a more streamlined group of participants—provides an opportunity to drive progress more effectively than the broader UN climate negotiations, which can sometimes face challenges in reaching consensus due to the diverse interests of key stakeholders, including major oil and gas producers. At COP27 in Sharm el-Sheikh (November 2022), South Africa presented its JETP Implementation Plan (JETP IP), outlining strategic investments in sectors like electricity, new energy vehicles, and green hydrogen. The plan, requiring USD 98 billion, underscored the immense scale of the transition and the financial resources necessary for a truly just transition. Indonesia followed suit at the G20 summit in Bali (November 2022), securing USD 20 billion in JETP financing. The agreement aims to peak power sector emissions by 2030—seven years earlier than planned—and includes ambitious carbon reduction targets.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 3 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Just Energy Transition Partnerships (JETP) in countries

content.text: Just Energy Transition Partnerships (JETPs) are collaborative initiatives aimed at facilitating the transition from fossil fuels to renewable energy in developing economies. JETPs typically involve financial and technical support from developed countries and international organizations to help developing countries phase out coal and other fossil fuels, promote renewable energy, and support affected workers and communities . However, while JETPs have shown promise in theory, their implementation has faced several significant challenges. To gain a deeper understanding of the practical challenges and opportunities associated with JETPs, Indonesia's JETP offers a great illustration. This case study sheds light on the complexities and nuances of implementing such a partnership in a developing country, highlighting both the successes and the obstacles faced along the way

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 3 | Part 2 | A
content.title: A. Just Energy Transition Partnerships In Indonesia

content.text: Indonesia's Just Energy Transition Partnership (JETP) was launched at the G20 summit in Bali, involving a substantial $20 billion financial package over three to five years. The partnership aims to accelerate Indonesia's transition from coal to renewable energy, with a commitment to peak power sector emissions by 2030, ahead of the previously planned 2037. This initiative is a collaborative effort, drawing on financial and technical support from international donors and private sector investments. The financial package for Indonesia's JETP is heavily reliant on concessional loans and commercial loans, with grants forming the smallest portion. This structure has faced criticism for being insufficiently different from traditional financing methods, thus not fully addressing the fiscal constraints of a developing economy. The reliance on loans, even if concessional, imposes a debt burden on Indonesia, which could limit its capacity to invest in other critical areas.

Despite the high-profile announcement, the mobilization and utilization of funds have been slow. The disbursement of funds and the execution of projects have faced significant delays, undermining the credibility of the JETP and raising concerns about its effectiveness. Bureaucratic inertia, lack of coordination among stakeholders, and the complexity of aligning international funding with national priorities are major obstacles to timely and efficient implementation. Moreover, Indonesia’s political landscape poses substantial challenges, with entrenched interests in state-owned enterprises which prefer traditional energy technologies such as hydropower and fossil fuels. These entities resist changes that threaten their economic interests, creating significant barriers to the adoption of renewable energy. There is a significant risk of greenwashing within the JETP framework. In Indonesia, some state-owned companies propose projects that maintain fossil fuel activities while incorporating minor renewable components to enhance their green credentials. Such practices undermine the credibility and effectiveness of the JETP, failing to achieve genuine environmental benefits.

Indonesia’s experience with the JETP highlights that while the initiative holds significant promise, addressing the financial, political, and social challenges is crucial for its success. To enhance the effectiveness and impact, JETPs must Increase the proportion of grants and innovative financial instruments discussed earlier and reduce reliance on loans to make the financial packages more attractive and feasible for developing countries. Developing a country platform approach could improve coordination and ownership of JETPs. This approach would involve a nationally owned institutional venue bringing together domestic policymakers, international investors, and technical experts to develop and manage investment plans. It is equally significant to set clear, ambitious targets for emissions reductions and renewable energy adoption, backed by robust monitoring and evaluation frameworks, is crucial. This includes ensuring that the transition plans are aligned with national development goals and international climate commitments.

Effective implementation of JETPs can significantly impact the debt burden of participating countries by providing financial relief and fostering economic stability. By offering concessional financing, grants, and technical assistance, JETPs reduce the immediate fiscal pressures on governments, allowing them to reallocate resources towards debt servicing and other critical needs. JETPs can also improve a country’s creditworthiness by promoting sustainable energy projects and reducing reliance on volatile fossil fuel markets. This enhancement in economic stability can lead to lower borrowing costs and better access to international capital markets. For example, South Africa's JETP involves an $8.5 billion financial package from G7 countries aimed at facilitating the transition away from coal, which can ease the country's debt burden by providing alternative funding sources for essential projects.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 3 | Part 2 | B
content.title: B. Just Energy Transition Partnership in South Africa

content.text: During the 26th Conference of the Parties under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change Conference (COP26) in 2021, the governments of South Africa, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, the United States of America, and the European Union announced the goal of creating a long-term Just Energy Transition Partnership (JETP) to aid South Africa in its decarbonization initiatives, particularly in transitioning to clean energy.

The JETP's main goals, supported by a financial pledge of USD 8.5 billion over 3-5 years, are to speed up South Africa's electricity sector's move towards decarbonization, safeguard workers and communities impacted by the shift from fossil fuels, aid in the necessary reforms to enhance the environment for a fair transition and promote technical innovation and investment from both public and private sectors.

The JETP created an International Partners Group (IPG) consisting of delegates from its member governments to coordinate activities among its members and with the South African government. The IPG collaborates with multilateral development banks and development finance institutions, which play a crucial role in implementing the JETP. The JETP is backed by a secretariat currently funded and aided by the Climate Investment Funds that are based administratively at the World Bank. The South African JETP will create five working groups to utilize technical expertise and experience to assist in achieving its goals. The JETP's comprehensive program and governance structure offers a robust framework to enhance the coherence and predictability of international support. The clearly defined medium priorities of the JETP can provide a clear signal to the market about South Africa's strong commitment to energy transition, despite the private sector not being formally represented in the program. The JETP model has been extended to other countries, including Indonesia and Vietnam.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 3 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: Challenges and concerns

content.text: Despite their promise, JETPs differ from traditional multilateral negotiations, raising questions about governance, financial mechanisms, and equity. Concerns have emerged about their impact on existing financial mechanisms, like the Green Climate Fund, and whether they adequately address global climate finance obligations. Critical voices underscore the imperative for a just (energy) transition to prioritize grassroots involvement and extend its reach to both national and local levels. Stakeholders emphasize the need for seamless integration of JETPs into national strategies and development blueprints, advocating for a harmonious alignment rather than reshaping national agendas to accommodate JETP objectives. Notably concerning is the opacity surrounding JETP governance, with limited public access to crucial information such as the engagement of the International Partners Group (IPG) with recipient nations, resource disbursement, and formal agreements.

Equity and inclusivity are critical to balancing cost-efficiency with a just transition. Addressing obstacles related to political economy, policy alignment, investment, and finance strategies is essential for successful JETP implementation. Furthermore, JETPs must avoid creating "debt traps," as some critics have suggested is a risk with current funding models. Indonesia has established a National Energy Transition Task Force and the JETP Secretariat to coordinate stakeholder engagements and oversee planning and project development. The country’s first coherent energy transition roadmap, the CIPP, with a budget of USD 97 billion, aims to ensure a just and inclusive transition. The framework is built on three key concepts: human rights, gender equality and empowerment, and accountability. While there is no one-size-fits-all solution, the establishment of commissions or task forces has proven effective in coordinating just energy transitions. These entities facilitate economic diversification and job creation across sectors like agriculture, tourism, and industry. Without such coordination, unjust transitions—such as direct job losses without reemployment—are a real risk.

content.title: KEY TAKEAWAYS
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Just Energy Transition Partnerships as Catalysts for Targeted Climate Finance
takeaways.description: JETPs represent a focused and collaborative financing mechanism designed to support developing countries in transitioning from fossil fuels to clean energy. By mobilizing both public and private capital, JETPs address critical gaps in funding for coal phase-outs, grid modernization, and workforce retraining, offering a more streamlined approach compared to broader multilateral climate negotiations.

takeaways.title: Integration of JETPs into National Strategies is Crucial for Equity and Inclusivity
takeaways.description: For JETPs to succeed, they must be seamlessly integrated into national energy transition roadmaps and development plans, ensuring alignment with local priorities rather than imposing external agendas. Establishing dedicated task forces, as seen in Indonesia, can enhance coordination, stakeholder engagement, and accountability, fostering a transition that prioritizes human rights, gender equality, and social inclusion.

takeaways.title: Transparency and Governance are Key to Avoiding Debt Traps and Ensuring Just Outcomes
takeaways.description: While JETPs offer significant financial support, concerns about governance, transparency, and equity remain. Ensuring public access to information on resource allocation, stakeholder engagement, and formal agreements is essential to prevent debt traps and ensure that the benefits of the transition are equitably distributed across national and local levels.
